instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 0.9v
threads.message:
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>

second post today (sorry no easy boards for me today)

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - 0.9v short to ground.

removed f7700 - short not on LCDBKLT side
removed f7140 no short on pin 1 (if apply power with this removed voltage is 8.5v)
short to ground on system side (pin 2 F7140 onwards)


tried removeing <TRANSISTOR>Q3080</TRANSISTOR> no change
removed <TRANSISTOR>Q5500</TRANSISTOR> no change.
replaced <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>
removed <CAPACITOR>C7582</CAPACITOR> <CAPACITOR>C7540</CAPACITOR> as got hot, no change 
removed <RESISTOR>R5450</RESISTOR> -went from diode mode 0v drop to 0.022 drop with <RESISTOR>R5450</RESISTOR> removed <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> goes to 7.4v
replaced with donor <RESISTOR>R5450</RESISTOR> get short again (0v drop diode mode pin2 F7140)

looking on my schematic i can't find <RESISTOR>R5450</RESISTOR> - although it is present on the board. Looks like its labelled <RESISTOR>R5400</RESISTOR> on the schematic.

Tried removing <CHIP>U5450</CHIP> (brd) <CHIP>U5400</CHIP> (schematic) no change

Injecting voltage it took 2A and 0.6v and <TRANSISTOR>Q7430</TRANSISTOR> got boiling hot, i removed it but the short still remains. 

Any suggestions gratefully received.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 0.9v
threads.message: Measure resistance between <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> to L7310 and L7320, there is a big chance that this board is a donor board now......

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 0.9v
threads.message: All of the haswell quad cores are complete pieces of shit when it comes to liquid around the edge. The slightest hint of liquid and CPU shorts <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> to ground.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 0.9v
threads.message: Thanks guys. Resistance (not diode mode) between pins 1 on 7310 and 7320 and <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> (F7140) is 22ohms. Diode mode voltage drop to ground on pins 1&2 of L7310 and L7320 is 0.012v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 0.9v
threads.message: I can say quite certain this board has been thoroughly fried, rabbit hole to hell, avoid.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 0.9v
